ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES



MPLX Terminals LLC (MPLX) - North Muskegon LP Terminal is a refined petroleum products distributor. The North Muskegon Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of North Muskegon, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.



The North Muskegon LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.



The North Muskegon Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented, including:



A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;

B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;

C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;

D. An overview of the emergency response program; and

E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.



A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The primary function of the North Muskegon Terminal is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 process

es were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community along with the surrounding environment. MPLX - North Muskegon Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety/control devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the North Muskegon Terminal.



The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in two (2) storage vessels. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The butane is pumped to an injection skid for direct injection into blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the injection skid and analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees Fahrenheit) fusible elements (fail safe valves), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shutoff devices on the system and video display terminal, thermal and pressure reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the North Muskegon Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.



B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC

PREVENTION MEASURES



MPLX's accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by regulated substances to employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68

as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the North Muskegon Terminal:



1) Employee Participation

2) Process Safety Information

3) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

4) Standard Operating Procedures

5) Operator Training

6) Contractor Safety

7) Pre-startup Safety Review

8) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance

9) Work Permits

10) Management of Change

11) Accident or Potential Catastrophic Event Investigation

12) Emergency Response

13) Compliance Audits

14) Trade Secrets



These fourteen (14) individual elements of the prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. MPLX and its employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, there are also specific prevention measures that are employed as part of the Terminal's operating procedures and engineering/administrative controls to help contain/control, quickly detect and reduce the consequences of a release. These are briefly summarized as follows:



General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures



-Engineering and construction in accordance with recognized industry and company standards

-Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure (pressure safety relief valves, etc.)

-Updated technical drawings, Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process Flow Diagrams

-Operating systems monitored and controlled by trained Operators

-Computerized monitoring (local and remote) and control of process operation

-Redundant control systems with battery back-ups

-Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems

-Scheduled inspection and testing of instruments, analyzers, and safety devices

-Controlled facility access

-Regular safety meetings and safety awareness programs

-Routinely scheduled safety inspections and audits

-Frequent unit surveillance by operators



General Release Mitigation



-Automati

c and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity

-Strategically located valves to isolate leaks

-Hydrocarbon detectors at key areas to warn of a chemical release and disable the process

-Fire monitors installed near the butane storage vessels and offload area with both auto and manual actuation



General Emergency Response



-Emergency alert system

-Periodic emergency training for employees

-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies

-Emergency drills with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies

-Mutual Aid with Local Fire Departments



Further, the North Muskegon LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Facility Response Plan (FRP)and Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) are in place with response activities being coordinated with the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department, North Muskegon Fire Department, and Muskegon County Emergency Services.



C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The North Muskegon Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal maintains records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at its facility. There have been no reportable accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the release of materials covered under the EPA RMP regulation.



D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



A Facility Response Plan (FRP) and Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) are in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.  The FRP and ERAP are part of a comprehensive response plan identified as "Smart Plan".



North Muskegon Terminal maintain a relat

ionship with the Muskegon Charter Township Fire Department and North Muskegon Fire Department. Tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are held routinely. These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the terminal.



E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



MPLX and its business partner continue to work toward improved coordination of process safety information and MOC implementation improvements focusing on procedures that mesh into both parties management systems.
